snippet.title: Tesla slides following news the company is offering $1.5 billion of junk bonds
snippet.content:
Shares of at $US355.53 a piece after the company announced on Monday it will be issue bonds to raise .
After the announcement, Standard & Poor's gave the bonds a B- rating, putting them in the high-risk junk bond category. Moody's assigned a similar B3 rating to the bonds.
"We could lower our ratings on Tesla if execution issues related to the Model 3 launch later this year or the ongoing expansion of its Models S and X production lead to significant cost overruns,"
According to Bank of America Merrill Lynch, , but factors like the lack of a long credit history and the "green" nature of the company could affect the rate.
Tesla is going into as it begins to produce its first mass-market vehicle, the Model 3, according to CEO Elon Musk.
Right now, the company is faster than ever, and only has if it continues at its current rate, according to hedge fund manager David Einhorn.
Shares of Tesla are up 65.59% this year.
